resources.string: Nutritional value of common fruits and meals!
Effective and short exercises to stay in shape!

Calories: 94.6, Protein: 0.43g, Carbs: 25.1g, Sugar: 18.9g, 
 Fiber: 4.37g 

 One of the world's most popular fruit, the apple is nature's sweet treat being high in fiber, antioxidants, and vitamin C to help you feel filled, manage blood sugar levels, and improve digestion (Arnarson, 2023). 

 Reference:
 Arnarson, A. (2023). Apples 101: Nutrition Facts and Health Benefits. Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/foods/apples

Calories: 89, Protein: 1.1g, Carbs: 22.8g, Sugar: 12.2g, 
 Fiber: 2.6g 

 A softer fruit, bananas are packed with vitamins, such as potassium to regulate heart health, and Vitamin B6 and C to manage blood sugar and promote a sense of being filled (Arnarson, 2023). 

 Reference:
 Arnarson, A. (2023). Bananas 101: Nutrition Facts and Health Benefits. Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/foods/bananas

Calories: 104, Protein: 1g, Carbs: 27g, Sugar: 23g, 
 Fiber: 1.4g 

 With a cup of red or green grapes, this fruit is packed with nutrients to help manage heart health, reduce cholesterol, and improve bone and eye health (Lang, 2023). 

 Reference: 
 Lang, A. (2023). The Top 16 Health Benefits of Grapes. Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/benefits-of-grapes

Calories: 190, Protein: 18g, Carbs: 6g, Sugar: 6g, 
 Fiber: 0g 

 A high protein snack, greek yogurt provides calcium for strong bones, probiotics for gut health, and contains various vitamins (Joseph, 2023). Mix with fruit, nuts, and granola to create a balanced snacked. 

 Reference: 
 Joseph, M. (2023). Greek Yogurt 101: Nutrition Facts and Health Benefits. Nutrition Advance. https://www.nutritionadvance.com/greek-yogurt-nutrition-benefits/

Calories: 157–204, Protein: 2–7g, Carbs: 3–9g, Sugar: 0g, 
 Fiber: 1-3g 

 Nuts like almonds, pistachios, walnuts, cashews, pecans, Brazil nuts, hazelnuts, and peanuts provide no significant amount of sugar and sodium when consumed raw, providing a protein filled alternative to chips, a crunchy way to get nutrients and vitamins, and they pair well with fruits and yogurt (Robertson & Kubala, 2024). 

 Reference: 
 Robertson, R., Kubala, J. (2024). The Top 9 Nuts to Eat for Better Health. Healthline. https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/9-healthy-nuts

Calories: 190, Protein: 7g, Carbs: 8g, Sugar: 3g, 
 Fiber: 2g 

 A tasty versatile spread classified with the nuts and seed category, this snack is a good source of protein, carbs, and healthy fats when consumed in moderation. Can help manage weight, reduce the risk of heart disease, and aid in building muscle (Frey, 2024). 

 Reference: 
 Frey, M. (2024). Peanut Butter Calories and Nutrition Facts. Verywell Fit. https://www.verywellfit.com/is-peanut-butter-good-for-you-3495231

Maintain a strong form with push ups that work the chest, triceps, and shoulder muscles with just the weight of your body. \n\n Start kneeled with hands shoulder width apart. Move one leg behind at a time, keeping them together like a plank. Start lowering your body by using your hands, abs, and legs to prevent falling on the ground. Once your chest touches the ground, use your hands, abs, and legs to push yourself back up, completing a repetition. Do as much as you can, until your body gets used to performing push ups. Start on your knees if unable to perform push ups in a plank position. Make it more challenging by doing push ups at different elevations or adding more weight with a backpack. Make sure your body is straight throughout.

A lower body exercise that works the quads and hamstring muscles, squats help build the legs without needing much space. \n\n Start by setting your feet about shoulder width apart, making sure your legs are in a comfortable position. Bend your knees until they cover your feet, using your hands to keep your balance. Start going up by pushing your feet towards the ground until your legs are straight, completing a repetition. Make sure your back is straight throughout.

An exercise that works the mid-section of the body, crunches allows you to work out your body while laying down. \n\n Start by finding a comfortable place to lay down, making sure your clothing does not hinder your movements. Lift your knees up at a comfortable angle, and begin lifting your body by squeezing you mid-section/stomach. When able to look over your knees, slowly go back down at the starting position to complete a repetition.

A more intense exercise, burpees will have you moving and sweating in no time with just a few simple movements. \n\n Start by being in a standing position. Then, follow the push ups positioning until you are at the plank position. At the plank position, go back up to the standing position and perform a low vertical jump to complete a repetition. Start off slow until you get used to the movements, then gradually increase your speed to make things more difficult. For more of a challenge, throw in push ups and squats between the movements to create a dynamic full body exercise.

Get your back stronger by pulling objects with different grip and standing positions. \n\n Start by bending your knees slightly. Using either an overhand or underhand grip, squeeze your back to move your arms back. Return to the starting position to complete a repetition. To work your upper back, start at a standing position. Try to do a shrug using both the left and right shoulders, keeping your arms straight. Relax to complete a repetition. Try using bottles, gallons, grocery bags, and other objects as weight to make each variation difficult without needing professional equipment.
Would you like to delete this data?
